columns.text: This exercise requires us to determine the stock price and new outstanding share of each situation.

First let's identify the given figures in the problem.

| | Amounts| 
|--|--:| 
|Shares Outstanding | 530,000| 
| Stock Price|$ 68 |

## Requirement a

**Stock split** increases the number of share in a company and cause a decrease of market price of individual shares.

First, we will compute the stock price given that **the company has five-for-three stock split**. It is computed by multiplying the share price by the number of stock split.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Share Price} &= \text{Share price}\times{\text{Share split}}\\[5pt]
&= \text{\$\hspace{5pt}68}\times{\dfrac{3}{5}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}40.80}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the new share price after the stock split is **$40.80**.

Next, we will compute the new shares outstanding after the stock split.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Shares Outstanding} &= \text{Share Outstanding}\times{\text{Share split}}\\[5pt]
&= \text{530,000}\times{\dfrac{5}{3}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{883,333 shares}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the new shares outstanding after the stock split are **883,333 shares**.

## Requirement b

**Stock dividend** is a dividend payment to shareholders that is made in shares rather than as cash. It can be classified as small share dividends and large share dividends.

If the shares issued is less than 20% of the total number of shares outstanding, it is considered as **small share dividends**, Whereas, If the shares issued is 20% or more of the total number of shares outstanding, it is considered as **large share dividends**.

Now, we will compute the new share price given that the company has a 15 percent stock dividend. Since it is less than 20% of shares outstanding, it is a **small share dividends**. Hence, the new share price is computed as follows:


$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Share Price} &= \dfrac{\text{Share Price}}{\text{1-r}}\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$
Where:

r - percentage of stock dividends

Applying the formula in new share price:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Share Price} &= \dfrac{\text{Share Price}}{\text{1 + r}}\\[10pt]
 &= \dfrac{\text{\$ 68}}{\text{1 + 0.15}}\\[10pt]
 &= \dfrac{\text{\$ 68}}{\text{1.15}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}59.13}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the new share price after the stock dividend is **$59.13**.

Next, we will compute the new shares outstanding after the stock dividend.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Shares Outstanding} &= \text{Share Outstanding}\times{\text{(1+r})}\\[5pt]
&= \text{530,000}\times{\text{(1+ 0.15})}\\[5pt]
&= \text{530,000}\times{\text{1.15}}\\[5pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{609,500 shares}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the new shares outstanding after the stock dividend are **609,500 shares**.

## Requirement c

Next, we will compute the new share price given that the company has a 42.5 percent stock dividend. Since it is more than 20% of shares outstanding, it is a **large share dividends**. We can now compute the new share price using the equation in step 7.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Share Price} &= \dfrac{\text{Share Price}}{\text{1 + r}}\\[10pt]
 &= \dfrac{\text{\$ 68}}{\text{1 + 0.425}}\\[10pt]
 &= \dfrac{\text{\$ 68}}{\text{1.425}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}47.72}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the new share price after the stock dividend is **$47.72**.

Next, we will compute the new shares outstanding after the stock dividend.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Shares Outstanding} &= \text{Share Outstanding}\times{\text{(1+r})}\\[5pt]
&= \text{530,000}\times{\text{(1+ 0.425})}\\[5pt]
&= \text{530,000}\times{\text{1.425}}\\[5pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{755,250 shares}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the new shares outstanding after the stock dividend are **755,250 shares**.

## Requirement d

**Reverse share split** decreases  the number of share in a company and cause a increase of market price of individual shares.

First, we will compute the stock price given that **the company has a four-for-seven reverse stock split**. It is computed by multiplying the share price by the number of reverse stock split.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Share Price} &= \text{Share price}\times{\text{Reverse share split}}\\[5pt]
&= \text{\$\hspace{5pt}68}\times{\dfrac{7}{4}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}119}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the new share price after the reverse stock split is **$119**.

Next, we will compute the new shares outstanding after the stock split.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Shares Outstanding} &= \text{Share Outstanding}\times{\text{Reverse Share split}}\\[5pt]
&= \text{530,000}\times{\dfrac{4}{7}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{302,857 shares}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the new shares outstanding after the stock split are **302,857 shares**.
